channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: O.C. deputy under investigation after wearing extremist paramilitary patch at George Floyd protest
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: Orange County Sheriff Don Barnes denounced a deputy who was pictured wearing a patch of the Three Percenters paramilitary group while policing a Costa Mesa protest.
item.content:encoded: Orange County Sheriff Don Barnes denounced a deputy who was pictured wearing a patch of the Three Percenters paramilitary group while policing a Costa Mesa protest.

item.title: Driver arrested on suspicion of pepper-spraying protesters after video goes viral
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan
item.description: Protesters were chanting "Black Lives Matter," when a driver pepper-sprayed them, captured in a video that went viral on TikTok and Twitter.
item.content:encoded: Protesters were chanting "Black Lives Matter," when a driver pepper-sprayed them, captured in a video that went viral on TikTok and Twitter.

media:content.media:description: Amy Atkisson was arrested after authorities said she pepper-sprayed a protester.

item.title: Column: No, white people. You can't ease your guilt over racism by paying black people via Cash App
item.dc:creator: Erika D. Smith
item.description: Since George Floyd died, black people are getting messages and money from white people they barely know. Here are the dos and don'ts of being a white ally.
item.content:encoded: Since George Floyd died, black people are getting messages and money from white people they barely know. Here are the dos and don'ts of being a white ally.

media:content.media:description: ANAHEIM CA. JUNE 3, 2020 - A group of demonstrators stage a sit-in in front of the Anaheim Civic Center Wednesday, June 3, 2020, to protest the in-custody death of George Floyd. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A.'s nighttime curfew faces growing criticism as arrests mount
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry, Matt Hamilton, Brittny Mejia
item.description: L.A.'s nighttime curfew criticized as overkill
item.content:encoded: L.A.'s nighttime curfew criticized as overkill

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA JUNE 2, 2020: Arrests made for curfew vilotation after a day of peaceful protest against police brutality and to demonstrate in Los Angeles, CA. The protests were sparked by the death of George Floyd. (Francine Orr/ Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Fundraiser pleads guilty in L.A. City Hall corruption case
item.dc:creator: Joel Rubin
item.description: A political operative pleaded guilty to helping to bribe a city councilmember
item.content:encoded: A political operative pleaded guilty to helping to bribe a city councilmember

media:content.media:description: It wasn't so much that voters rejected female candidates for the 11 offices on this year's ballot, although Wendy Greuel and Jan Perry were both serious candidates for mayor, and Ana Cubas made the runoff in the 9th Council District race but fell short. But there were no women at all running for city attorney or controller, or for several of the City Council offices. From July 1, when the all-male victors took office, to Aug. 2, when they were joined by new Councilwoman Nury Martinez, Los Angeles City Hall had no elected women in office for the first time in decades. Above: L.A. City Hall. MORE YEAR IN REVIEW: Ted Rall's five best cartoons of 2013 6 developments that changed Latin America in 201310 tips for a better life from The Times' Op-Ed pages in 2013

item.title: Newsom says California would 'reject' Trump's attempts to send military into major cities
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Cosgrove, Taryn Luna
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom said California will reject President Donald Trump's threats to send military into states to control protests following the death of George Floyd.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom said California will reject President Donald Trump's threats to send military into states to control protests following the death of George Floyd.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 03, 2020 - - California Governor Gavin Newsom, from left, helps pack up lunches to be delivered to needy senior citizens, along with Hot and Cool Cafe co-owner Shana Jenson, Los Angeles Supervisor Mark Ridley-Thomas and California Assembly Member Sydney Kamlager-Dove, right, during a visit to the cafe in Leimert Park after several days of protest in Los Angeles on June 3, 2020. The cafe has been providing meals prepared at the establishment 3 days a week for senior citizens during the coronavirus pandemic stay at home order. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Among California reopenings: Pickleball courts. So, what's pickleball?
item.dc:creator: Maria Torres
item.description: Parks and other facilities are reopening in California, including pickleball courts. Here's what pickleball is, how to play and where to find equipment.
item.content:encoded: Parks and other facilities are reopening in California, including pickleball courts. Here's what pickleball is, how to play and where to find equipment.

media:content.media:description: EL SEGUNDO, CA - MAY 26: From left: Melanie Archer, of Inglewood, rallies with Sheila Payne at El Segundo Park on Tuesday, May 26, 2020 in El Segundo, CA. Archer and Payne met last year at the El Segundo courts, when a group of pickleball players would gather to play. They are also a part of a pickle ball text group that is used to plan meetups. (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Pediatricians say kids should be in school despite coronavirus risk
item.dc:creator: Sonali Kohli
item.description: Research suggests that the risks of COVID-19 transmission among children are lower than for adults.
item.content:encoded: Research suggests that the risks of COVID-19 transmission among children are lower than for adults.

media:content.media:description: GLENDALE, CA - MAY 26: Los Angeles County Office of Education Supt. Debra Duardo, left, and Glendale Unified Supt. Vivian Ekchian, right, are given a tour of Cerritos Elementary in Glendale by Principal Perla Chavez-Fritz, center, on Tuesday May 26, 2020 considering that with a persisting coronavirus threat, K-12 campuses will try to reopen in the fall. New L.A. County guidelines offer a possible roadmap but it could get complicated and costly to confront the logistics of reopening at an actual school in the wake of Covid-19. Glendale on Tuesday, May 26, 2020 in Glendale, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California counties are reopening despite continued rise in coronavirus cases
item.dc:creator: Deborah Netburn
item.description: L.A. County's coronavirus testing sites have been operating under shortened hours because of protests as the county nears 2,500 COVID-19 deaths.
item.content:encoded: L.A. County's coronavirus testing sites have been operating under shortened hours because of protests as the county nears 2,500 COVID-19 deaths.

media:content.media:description: SAN PEDRO, CA - MAY 29: Server Sloane Sires, of Long Beach carries a tray of drinks as people dine in at the San Pedro Brewing Company on Friday, May 29, 2020 in San Pedro, CA. On Friday, Los Angeles County received permission to reopen restaurants for in-person dining and resume services at barbershops and hair salons, marking a new phase in the regions efforts to restart the devastated retail economy. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 12th inmate at Chino prison dies after testing positive for COVID-19
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: A 12th inmate at Chino prison dies after testing positive for COVID-19 as California officials try to stem outbreaks at three state prisons.
item.content:encoded: A 12th inmate at Chino prison dies after testing positive for COVID-19 as California officials try to stem outbreaks at three state prisons.

media:content.media:description: A 2009 photo of Chino state prison, where Michael Ray Morrow escaped in 1977. He was arrested Tuesday in Arkansas, the FBI says.
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Looters drive off with $90,000 muscle cars in San Leandro over weekend, police say
item.dc:creator: Kristi Sturgill
item.description: San Leandro police were 'overwhelmed' by looters Sunday night, who made off with more than 70 vehicles valued at over $2.7 million.
item.content:encoded: San Leandro police were 'overwhelmed' by looters Sunday night, who made off with more than 70 vehicles valued at over $2.7 million.

item.title: 'Heartbreaking': These families were set to adopt, but coronavirus put their plans on hold
item.dc:creator: Seema Mehta
item.description: Coronavirus-prompted court closures are making thousands of California families wait to adopt as their hearings are pushed farther and farther back.
item.content:encoded: Coronavirus-prompted court closures are making thousands of California families wait to adopt as their hearings are pushed farther and farther back.

media:content.media:description: Stephanie Rivero and Ryan Cameron carry their foster sons, ages 5 and 8. The Merced couple's adoption of the boys has been pushed back because of the court closures during the pandemic. That may delay the younger boy's planned surgery for a live-threatening condition.

item.title: Santa Ana man threw fireworks at police during protest, authorities say
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan
item.description: After arresting the man at his home, police said they found more than 600 pounds of illegal fireworks and a cache of weapons and ammunition.
item.content:encoded: After arresting the man at his home, police said they found more than 600 pounds of illegal fireworks and a cache of weapons and ammunition.

media:content.media:description: Santa Ana police arrested Jon Paul Worden after officers said he threw mortars at law enforcement officials during a protest May 31. Police found a cache of weapons and ammunition in his home.

item.title: Newsom orders new California in-person voting rules for November election
item.dc:creator: John Myers
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom will allow California counties to provide fewer in-person voting locations if they also offer three days of early voting.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom will allow California counties to provide fewer in-person voting locations if they also offer three days of early voting.

media:content.media:description: Dorr Looman votes at Malibu Hindu Temple polling station in the state primary election on June 7, 2016 in Calabasas, California.

item.title: LAPD Chief Michel Moore's comments on looters create political firestorm
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton, Cindy Chang, Benjamin Oreskes
item.description: Los Angeles Police Chief Michel Moore apologized minutes after condemning looters and saying George Floyd's 'death is on their hands.'
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles Police Chief Michel Moore apologized minutes after condemning looters and saying George Floyd's 'death is on their hands.'

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -- MAY 30: Michel Moore, second from left, Chief of Police for the Los Angeles Police Department, lets protestors who are demonstrating that the area is closed at W 3rd St and S Fairfax Ave. in the Fairfax District on Saturday, May 30, 2020, in Los Angeles, CA. The protestors demonstrate in response to the death of George Floyd in Minnesota. Last night more than 500 arrests after looting and vandalism sweep downtown L.A. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California's legal pot industry faces year of decline because of coronavirus, Newsom warns
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: California's legal marijuana industry faces a year of decline as a result of the coronavirus, despite dispensaries being deemed essential businesses.
item.content:encoded: California's legal marijuana industry faces a year of decline as a result of the coronavirus, despite dispensaries being deemed essential businesses.

media:content.media:description: Sean McDermott (left), owner of The Grove cannabis shop in La Mesa, looks over one of the store's products with Larry Fennell, one of his first hires from the summer of 2018. The site on Center Street was the first in East County authorized by California to sell adult-use cannabis products. McDermott said he received confirmation from the state by mail on May 6 and The Grove had its first recreational cannabis product sale on May 7.

item.title: Protests planned for Newport Beach after tense standoff at South Coast Plaza
item.dc:creator: Gustavo Arellano, Ben Brazil, Hillary Davis
item.description: Four demonstrations, at least one of them billed as family friendly, are scheduled across Newport Beach on Wednesday.
item.content:encoded: Four demonstrations, at least one of them billed as family friendly, are scheduled across Newport Beach on Wednesday.

media:content.media:description: There was a series of standoffs between protesters and police at a rally at South Coast Plaza late Monday night.

item.title: 'Defund LAPD' becomes a rallying cry at protests. Unrest has intensified the debate
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes, David Zahniser, Dakota Smith
item.description: Progressive activists want the City Council to slash spending at the LAPD.
item.content:encoded: Progressive activists want the City Council to slash spending at the LAPD.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 02: Law enforcement personnel stand in front of LAPD HQ as demonstrators chant in downtown Los Angeles on Tuesday, June 2, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Protests have erupted across the country, with people outraged over the death of George Floyd, a black man killed after a white Minneapolis police officer pinned him to the ground with his knee. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'A good army': L.A. protesters from diverse backgrounds converge on streets
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia, Julia Wick, Matt Hamilton, Jaclyn Cosgrove, Dorany Pineda, Alejandra Reyes-Velarde, Liam Dillon
item.description: Thousands peacefully took to the street in Hollywood and DTLA in what appeared to be the city's biggest protests since George Floyd's death last week.
item.content:encoded: Thousands peacefully took to the street in Hollywood and DTLA in what appeared to be the city's biggest protests since George Floyd's death last week.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 02: Recording artist Chela Alvarado, center, raises her arm joining protestors in front of National Guardsmen as they stand guard closing Sunset Blvd at Vine Street in Hollywood as protesters made of mostly students marched through Hollywood Tuesday afternoon to protest the death of George Floyd during an arrest in Minneapolis last week. The group gathered at the intersection of Hollywood Blvd and Vine Street for a peaceful demonstration and marched through parts of Hollywood encountering LAPD officers and National Guardsmen. Hollywood on Tuesday, June 2, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 2 wounded, 3 arrested after South L.A. shooting triggers police pursuit
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: Officers responded to Broadway and Manchester Avenue shortly after midnight after hearing gunshots.
item.content:encoded: Officers responded to Broadway and Manchester Avenue shortly after midnight after hearing gunshots.

media:content.media:description: Authorities surround a vehicle after a shooting in South Los Angeles triggered a police pursuit early Wednesday. (OnScene.TV)

item.title: UC dropped the SAT. Should you take it anyway?
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: The University of California made headlines by dropping SAT and ACT requirements. But students should still take them, many high school counselors say.
item.content:encoded: The University of California made headlines by dropping SAT and ACT requirements. But students should still take them, many high school counselors say.

media:content.media:description: PEMBROKE PINES, FL - MARCH 06: A college applicant uses an SAT Preparation book to study for the test on March 6, 2014 in Pembroke Pines, Florida.

item.title: L.A. Pride announces Black Lives Matter solidarity protest march for June 14
item.dc:creator: Jessica Roy
item.description: This year's L.A. Pride will be a peaceful protest march in solidarity with the Black Lives Matter movement, organizers announced. It will take place June 14 starting at Hollywood and Highland.
item.content:encoded: This year's L.A. Pride will be a peaceful protest march in solidarity with the Black Lives Matter movement, organizers announced. It will take place June 14 starting at Hollywood and Highland.

media:content.media:description: HERMOSA BEACH, CA - JUNE 02: Several hundred Black Lives Matter protesters take a knee and hold their fists in the air during a moment of silence to honor George Floyd during a peaceful protest march from Manhattan Beach to Hermosa Beach and return at the Hermosa Beach Pier Plaza Tuesday, June 2, 2020. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: South L.A. is largely untouched by unrest. That is by design
item.dc:creator: Angel Jennings
item.description: Black Lives Matter organizers wanted to bring the rage over the George Floyd case and so many others to L.A.'s elites, in their own neighborhoods.
item.content:encoded: Black Lives Matter organizers wanted to bring the rage over the George Floyd case and so many others to L.A.'s elites, in their own neighborhoods.

media:content.media:description: LAPD officer Delwin Fields guards the intersection at Central and 46th Street on April 30, 1992.

item.title: Hype and science collide as FDA tries to rein in 'wild West' of COVID-19 blood tests
item.dc:creator: JoNel Aleccia, Anna Maria Barry-Jester
item.description: The FDA is trying to rein in the chaos it created by allowing companies to flood the market with COVID-19 antibody tests of questionable accuracy.
item.content:encoded: The FDA is trying to rein in the chaos it created by allowing companies to flood the market with COVID-19 antibody tests of questionable accuracy.

media:content.media:description: In Mira Mesa, an employee takes a blood test to determine if he carries coronavirus antibodies.
media:content.media:credit: Nelvin C. Cepeda/The San Diego Union-Tribune

item.title: LAPD tactics get more aggressive as arrests soar
item.dc:creator: James Queally, Kevin Rector, Alejandra Reyes-Velarde, Richard Winton
item.description: With Los Angeles under nightly curfews and looting breaking out in neighborhoods across the city and county, arrests have surged into the thousands.
item.content:encoded: With Los Angeles under nightly curfews and looting breaking out in neighborhoods across the city and county, arrests have surged into the thousands.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA, Tuesday, June 2, 2020 - LAPD officer Decote watches for people tossing debris from tall buildings as dozens of protesters are arrested for curfew violations on Broadway. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Inland Empire protests fueled by cases of past police violence
item.dc:creator: Paloma Esquivel
item.description: Protests over the death of George Floyd also taking place in the Inland Empire, which has its own history of police abuses and violence.
item.content:encoded: Protests over the death of George Floyd also taking place in the Inland Empire, which has its own history of police abuses and violence.

media:content.media:description: RIVERSIDE, CA - JUNE 1, 2020: Thousands of demonstrators rallied in front of the Riverside Public Library to protest the death of George Floyd during the coronavirus pandemic on June 1, 2020 in Riverside, California. Police allowed them to stay 90 minutes after the 6pm curfew. Those that remained were dispersed as law enforcement fired tear gas and pellets.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California braces for second wave of coronavirus even as first wave is far from over
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Iris Lee, Colleen Shalby
item.description: Experts are worried about the potential for new surges of disease as California reopens.
item.content:encoded: Experts are worried about the potential for new surges of disease as California reopens.

media:content.media:description: ATWATER, CA - MAY 26, 2020 - - Randy Romero, one of the few wearing a mask to prevent COVID-19, says the Pledge of Allegiance at the start of the weekly Atwater City Council meeting in Atwater on May 26, 2020. The city of Atwater in Merced County has declared itself a "sanctuary city" from the state's stay-at-home orders and has been open for business for over a week now. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: Tolliver's barbershop in South Los Angeles is temporarily closed, but the conversation continues
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: I've known Lawrence Tolliver for two decades. I've never seen him this discouraged about the world.
item.content:encoded: I've known Lawrence Tolliver for two decades. I've never seen him this discouraged about the world.

media:content.media:description: Lawrence Tolliver, at his West Florence Avenue barbershop, says Ronald Reagan "never felt comfortable in our community. He never reached out to us, and we never reached out to him. So when we see the people on TV crying and weeping, it's hard for us to figure out why."

item.title: 61 people charged with looting, other crimes in L.A. as peaceful protests continue
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia, Dorany Pineda, Alejandra Reyes-Velarde, Julia Wick, Hannah Fry, Richard Winton, Luke Money
item.description: Sheriff Alex Villanueva extends a countywide curfew for a fourth day to keep protests and potential looting in check.
item.content:encoded: Sheriff Alex Villanueva extends a countywide curfew for a fourth day to keep protests and potential looting in check.

media:content.media:description: ANAHEIM, CA - JUNE 03: Protestors rally on the steps Anaheim City Hall steps against last week's in-custody death of George Floyd in Minneapolis City Hall on Wednesday, June 3, 2020 in Anaheim, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: UCLA protests LAPD using Jackie Robinson Stadium for protest arrest processing
item.dc:creator: Gale Holland
item.description: The school said it was "troubled" by reports that the stadium was used as a field jail.
item.content:encoded: The school said it was "troubled" by reports that the stadium was used as a field jail.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 02: LAPD officers moved a crowd of protestors up Cahuenga Blvd to Yucca in Hollywood to control protestors made of mostly students as they marched Tuesday afternoon to protest the death of George Floyd during an arrest in Minneapolis last week. The group gathered at the intersection of Hollywood Blvd and Vine Street for a peaceful demonstration and marched through parts of Hollywood encountering LAPD officers and National Guardsmen. Hollywood on Tuesday, June 2, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: USC will reopen for fall semester with online and in-person classes, more distancing in dorms
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: USC will bring students back to campus this fall, with online and in-person classes and more spacing in dorms as safety measures amid the coronavirus crisis, President Carol L. Folt announced Tuesday.
item.content:encoded: USC will bring students back to campus this fall, with online and in-person classes and more spacing in dorms as safety measures amid the coronavirus crisis, President Carol L. Folt announced Tuesday.

media:content.media:description: Bovard Auditorium seen from the steps of Doheny Library at USC. From 2006 to 2014, not a single woman ran for student body president.
media:content.media:credit: Perry C. Riddle / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Earthquake: 3.9 quake registered near Barstow, Calif.
item.dc:creator: Quakebot

item.content:encoded: A magnitude 3.9 earthquake was reported Tuesday evening at 9:36 p.m., 23 miles from Barstow, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

item.title: Thousands of protesters converge on Mayor Garcetti's residence, demand change
item.dc:creator: Matt Hamilton
item.description: Thousands of people gathered outside Mayor Eric Garcetti's residence and chanted in vigorous opposition to his response so far to citywide protests.
item.content:encoded: Thousands of people gathered outside Mayor Eric Garcetti's residence and chanted in vigorous opposition to his response so far to citywide protests.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA JUNE 2, 2020: Protestors gather outside Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti's Hancock Park house as they continue to demonstrate against police brutality and to demonstrate in Los Angeles, CA. in Los Angeles, CA June 2, 2020. The protests were sparked by the death of George Floyd. (Francine Orr/ Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Watch: Protesters in Pershing Square demand justice
item.dc:creator: LZ Granderson

item.content:encoded: Columnist LZ Granderson spoke with protesters in downtown Los Angeles and found a readiness toward goodwill and solidarity.

item.title: Scott Peterson asks court to overturn murder conviction and death sentence
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: A lawyer for Scott Peterson, convicted in 2004 of murdering his wife, Laci, told the California Supreme Court Tuesday that Peterson was denied a fair trial.
item.content:encoded: A lawyer for Scott Peterson, convicted in 2004 of murdering his wife, Laci, told the California Supreme Court Tuesday that Peterson was denied a fair trial.

media:content.media:description: Scott Peterson listens to prosecutor Joseph Distaso respond to defense attorney Mark Geragos' petition for dismissing double murder charges against Peterson on Jan. 14, 2004, in Modesto. Judge Marie Sovey Silveira denied the petition. Peterson was sentenced to death March 16, 2005.
media:content.media:credit: Pool photo by Bart Ah You

item.title: California's black lawmakers urge support for bills to address systemic inequality
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna
item.description: The California Legislative Black Caucus reflected on the death of George Floyd and urged the passage of several bills intended to address inequality in the state.
item.content:encoded: The California Legislative Black Caucus reflected on the death of George Floyd and urged the passage of several bills intended to address inequality in the state.

item.title: Mayor Garcetti takes a knee amid chants of 'Defund police!' at downtown L.A. protest
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Cosgrove, Tania Ganguli, Julia Wick, Hailey Branson-Potts, Matt Hamilton, Liam Dillon
item.description: Hundreds of peaceful demonstrators gathered in downtown Los Angeles on Tuesday to protest the death of George Floyd and police brutality against black people.
item.content:encoded: Hundreds of peaceful demonstrators gathered in downtown Los Angeles on Tuesday to protest the death of George Floyd and police brutality against black people.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 02: LA Mayor Eric Garcetti walks out to address protesters and clergy members from the Los Angeles area that are participating in a march and peaceful protest in downtown Los Angeles outside of LA City Hall and LAPD Headquarters on Tuesday, June 2, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Protests erupted across the country, with people outraged over the death of George Floyd, a black man killed after a white Minneapolis police officer pinned him to the ground with his knee. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Man with assault rifle impersonating National Guard arrested at downtown protest

item.description: Police said the man was confronted by real members of the National Guard at First and Main Street on Tuesday.
item.content:encoded: Police said the man was confronted by real members of the National Guard at First and Main Street on Tuesday.

media:content.media:credit: Myung J. Chun/Myung J. Chun/Los Angeles Times

item.title: By firing rubber bullets at protesters, police risk killing, blinding or maiming them
item.dc:creator: Liz Szabo
item.description: Five decades of evidence show that rubber bullets can maim, blind and even kill people, but they still are being used widely by police to quell protests and unrest.
item.content:encoded: Five decades of evidence show that rubber bullets can maim, blind and even kill people, but they still are being used widely by police to quell protests and unrest.

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CALIFORNIA MAY 31, 2020-A protestor is treated for a wound after being struck by a rubber bullet and before being arrested for unlawful assembly on 5th St. in Santa Maonica Sunday. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. Police Commission and Chief Moore hear from outraged residents
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton, Cindy Chang
item.description: During a marathon police commission meeting Tuesday, scores of residents directed anger and concern at LAPD Chief Michel Moore.
item.content:encoded: During a marathon police commission meeting Tuesday, scores of residents directed anger and concern at LAPD Chief Michel Moore.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 30: LAPD Chief of Police Michel Moore speaks with a protester in the Fairfax District on Saturday, May 30, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Protests erupted across the country, with people outraged over the death of George Floyd, a black man killed after a white Minneapolis police officer pinned him to the ground with his knee. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Shopkeepers board businesses in Van Nuys following night of looting
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Reyes-Velarde
item.description: Many stores remained closed after a day of peaceful protests erupted into an evening of looting.
item.content:encoded: Many stores remained closed after a day of peaceful protests erupted into an evening of looting.

media:content.media:description: VAN NUYS, CA - JUNE 02: Volunteers work to sort through cases of jewelry inventory in the Don Larry Watch & Jewelry Repair store on Hamlin Street just off Van Nuys Blvd. People roamed the Van Nuys shopping district Tuesday morning to clean up and remove debris in the aftermath of the protest and looting of businesses along Van Nuys Blvd as numerous stores were attacked and at least one set on fire. Protestors again gathered in the midst of the coronavirus outbreak to protest the death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man who died last week in police custody after a white Minneapolis police officer pinned him down by his neck for several minutes. Van Nuys on Tuesday, June 2, 2020 in Van Nuys, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'Then God said, "Hold my beer"': The inside story of the night that changed L.A. clubs forever
item.dc:creator: August Brown, Randall Roberts
item.description: An oral history of the coronavirus pandemic, as told by the staffs of four iconic L.A. nightclubs: the Troubadour, McCabe's Guitar Shop, Sound and the Satellite
item.content:encoded: An oral history of the coronavirus pandemic, as told by the staffs of four iconic L.A. nightclubs: the Troubadour, McCabe's Guitar Shop, Sound and the Satellite

media:content.media:description: Hollywood CA, Thursday, May 28, 2020 - Dance music-oriented Sound Nightclub staff, left to right, GM Artie Sinaplidis, owner Kobi Danan, and bartender Shailee Ben-David Sound is an upscale techno club in the heart of Hollywood-described BC(Before Covid) as a splashy DJ-fueled club with rotating art installations, bottle service & street-food-inspired bites. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: SAT plans for at-home tests suspended; some students may not have access to exams
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: The College Board scrambles to find testing sites and puts its efforts to develop an at-home exam on hold.
item.content:encoded: The College Board scrambles to find testing sites and puts its efforts to develop an at-home exam on hold.

media:content.media:description: NEW YORK - JUNE 27: SAT test preparation books sit on a shelf at a Barnes and Noble store June 27, 2002 in New York City. College Board trustees decided June 27 to add a written essay and other changes to the SAT in an overhaul of the college entrance exam. The first administration of the new SAT will occur in March of 2005. (Photo by Mario Tama/Getty Images) ** OUTS - ELSENT, FPG, CM - OUTS * NM, PH, VA if sourced by CT, LA or MoD **

item.title: What time are the curfews in and around L.A. tonight?
item.dc:creator: Maria Torres
item.description: Los Angeles County officials imposed a countywide curfew for the third consecutive day Tuesday, citing a desire to protect public safety amid ongoing protests. Some cities implemented even stricter limits.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County officials imposed a countywide curfew for the third consecutive day Tuesday, citing a desire to protect public safety amid ongoing protests. Some cities implemented even stricter limits.

media:content.media:description: RIVERSIDE, CA - JUNE 1, 2020: A lone protester tries to confront a line of advancing Riverside County Sheriff deputies and police ready to fire tear gas and pellets on demonstrators who refused to disperse after curfew during a protest against the death of George Floyd during the coronavirus pandemic on June 1, 2020 in Riverside, California. Thousands of protesters marched through the street of downtown Riverside and police alloyed them to stay 90 minutes after the 6pm curfew.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Over 1,000 protesters converge on Hollywood, are met by police
item.dc:creator: Dorany Pineda, Brittny Mejia
item.description: Shortly before noon, a large crowd gathered at Hollywood Boulevard and Vine Street to protest police brutality and the death of George Floyd.
item.content:encoded: Shortly before noon, a large crowd gathered at Hollywood Boulevard and Vine Street to protest police brutality and the death of George Floyd.

media:content.media:description: ANAHEIM, CA - JUNE 03: Protestors rally on the steps Anaheim City Hall steps against last week's in-custody death of George Floyd in Minneapolis City Hall on Wednesday, June 3, 2020 in Anaheim, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. halts storage-unit evictions during the coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Lila Seidman
item.description: A new L.A. law gives storage-unit renters the right to temporarily defer payment if they're facing pandemic-related financial difficulties.
item.content:encoded: A new L.A. law gives storage-unit renters the right to temporarily defer payment if they're facing pandemic-related financial difficulties.

media:content.media:description: A vehicle waits to enter the gates at the Public Storage on the 5500 block of SanFernando Rd. in Glendale on Tuesday, April 14, 2020.

item.title: Appeals court justice should be ousted for sexual misconduct, judicial watchdog says
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: State commission says Los Angeles-based Court of Appeal Justice Jeffrey Johnson should be removed from the bench for mistreatment of women.
item.content:encoded: State commission says Los Angeles-based Court of Appeal Justice Jeffrey Johnson should be removed from the bench for mistreatment of women.

media:content.media:description: Justice Jeffrey Johnson of the California 2nd District Court of Appeal

item.title: L.A. County reports 60 new coronavirus deaths as testing sites close for second day amid protests
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Ongoing protests over the death of George Floyd have momentarily halted progress in the fight against the coronavirus in Los Angeles County, as officials reported an additional 60 deaths and 1,202 new cases.
item.content:encoded: Ongoing protests over the death of George Floyd have momentarily halted progress in the fight against the coronavirus in Los Angeles County, as officials reported an additional 60 deaths and 1,202 new cases.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 18: Dr. Alexis Gomez, at St. John's Well Child and Family Center in South Los Angeles where walk-in testing is available for coronavirus Covid-19. The Center is located at 808 West 58th Street; one of the South and Central LA neighborhoods hit hard by the coronavirus Covid-19. South Central on Monday, May 18, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Bay Area police officer shoots break-in suspect near Walgreens in Vallejo
item.dc:creator: Kristi Sturgill
item.description: Police responded to a reported looting at Vallejo Walgreens, shooting one suspect and chasing another across Carquinez Bridge.
item.content:encoded: Police responded to a reported looting at Vallejo Walgreens, shooting one suspect and chasing another across Carquinez Bridge.

media:content.media:description: FILE - This June 24, 2019 file photo shows an exterior view of a Walgreens store in Los Angeles. Walgreens will pay $7.5 million to settle with California authorities after an employee was criminally charged with impersonating a pharmacist and illegally filling more than 745,000 prescriptions in the San Francisco Bay Area. Kim Thien Le has pleaded not guilty to felony impersonation charges. (AP Photo/Marcio Jose Sanchez,File)

item.title: Arrests during George Floyd protests swell to near 3,000 in L.A. County; many are locals
item.dc:creator: James Queally, Ben Welsh
item.description: Almost 2,700 people in Southern California have been arrested since Friday during protests of George Floyd's death and excessive force by police.
item.content:encoded: Almost 2,700 people in Southern California have been arrested since Friday during protests of George Floyd's death and excessive force by police.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 01: Protestors arrested for violating curfew along Sunset Blvd. at Gower in Hollywood on Monday, June 1, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Protests rage in Bay Area and Sacramento, with less tolerance of thieves and vandals
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust, Anita Chabria, Kristi Sturgill
item.description: Protests sparked by the killing of George Floyd continue in the Bay Area and Sacramento Monday, overall peaceful but with some incidents.
item.content:encoded: Protests sparked by the killing of George Floyd continue in the Bay Area and Sacramento Monday, overall peaceful but with some incidents.

media:content.media:description: Protesters chained together block the intersection of Broadway and 7th Street in front of the Oakland Police Department on Monday.

item.title: Self-proclaimed vampire suspected of killing fellow inmate in prison shower
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Authorities say Joshua Rudiger was in the showers at the California Health Care Facility in Stockton at the time a 40-year-old inmate was attacked.
item.content:encoded: Authorities say Joshua Rudiger was in the showers at the California Health Care Facility in Stockton at the time a 40-year-old inmate was attacked.

media:content.media:description: Joshua Rudiger, 42, is suspected of attacking and fatally wounding a fellow inmate at the California Health Care Facility in Stockton, authorities said.
media:content.media:credit: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation

item.title: Butte County, among earliest in California to reopen, reports 1st coronavirus-related death
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: There have been 51 coronavirus cases in Butte County, almost half reported in the two weeks since it was allowed to more fully reopen.
item.content:encoded: There have been 51 coronavirus cases in Butte County, almost half reported in the two weeks since it was allowed to more fully reopen.

media:content.media:description: This transmission electron microscope image shows SARS-CoV-2, also known as 2019-nCoV, the coronavirus virus that causes COVID-19
media:content.media:credit: (National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases Rocky Mountain Laboratories)

item.title: Coronavirus cases spike among Marin County essential workers as more testing is urged
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: Marin County has been reopening at a slower pace than other parts of California, cognizant of the potential for continued spread of the virus.
item.content:encoded: Marin County has been reopening at a slower pace than other parts of California, cognizant of the potential for continued spread of the virus.

media:content.media:description: A couple sits at a vista point with the San Francisco skyline in the background Friday, March 27, 2020, in Sausalito, Calif. The surge of coronavirus cases in California that health officials have warned was coming has arrived and will worsen, Gov. Gavin Newsom said Friday, while the mayor of Los Angeles warned that by early next week his city could see the kind of crush that has crippled New York.(AP Photo/Eric Risberg)

item.title: Sonoma County sheriff backtracks, says he will enforce coronavirus orders
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: Sheriff Mark Essick, who declared last week that his deputies would no longer enforce Sonoma County's coronavirus health order, has reversed course.
item.content:encoded: Sheriff Mark Essick, who declared last week that his deputies would no longer enforce Sonoma County's coronavirus health order, has reversed course.

media:content.media:description: In this photo taken Wednesday, April 1, 2020, are the empty grounds of the historic Buena Vista Winery in Sonoma, Calif. Wineries that want to stay viable and connected to their customers during the coronavirus pandemic are harnessing platforms such as Facebook Live to offer virtual wine experiences. Tasting rooms in California shut down last month after the governor ordered businesses to close to slow the spread of the new virus. (AP Photo/Eric Risberg)

item.title: LAPD, FBI collecting protest, looting footage as evidence for future arrests
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector, James Queally
item.description: The LAPD has been collecting evidence throughout the protests, mostly in the form of video, that could be used to identify people and bring charges.
item.content:encoded: The LAPD has been collecting evidence throughout the protests, mostly in the form of video, that could be used to identify people and bring charges.

media:content.media:description: People looted a watch and jewelry store on Monday in Van Nuys.

item.title: Banks: As protests roll on, demanding the justice that leads to peace
item.dc:creator: Sandy Banks
item.description: I was optimistic enough to believe that the spread of protests across the country signified a long-overdue national reckoning with the plague of police brutality. But looters and troublemakers hijacked some of the efforts.
item.content:encoded: I was optimistic enough to believe that the spread of protests across the country signified a long-overdue national reckoning with the plague of police brutality. But looters and troublemakers hijacked some of the efforts.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 01: Protests continue against police brutality and racial discrimination in the Hollywood CA. The protests were peacefull and were sparked by the death of George Floyd Monday, June 1, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Francine Orr / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Santa Cruz police chief took a knee during a George Floyd protest. Other police soon followed
item.dc:creator: Melissa Gomez
item.description: In an image captured by a local photojournalist, Santa Cruz Police Chief Andy Mills kneels to honor the memory of George Floyd.
item.content:encoded: In an image captured by a local photojournalist, Santa Cruz Police Chief Andy Mills kneels to honor the memory of George Floyd.

media:content.media:description: Santa Cruz, California Police Chief Andy Mills takes a knee along with hundreds gathered on Pacific Avenue in downtown Santa Cruz on Saturday May 30, 2020 to honor the memory of George Floyd and bring attention to institutionalized police violence against black people. Minneapolis resident George Floyd was pinned facedown on the ground, in handcuffs, by a white police officer who pressed his knee against Floyd's neck for more than eight minutes. He was unresponsive when paramedics arrived, and he was pronounced dead later. (Photo by Shmuel Thaler)
media:content.media:credit: Shmuel Thaler/Santa Cruz Sentinel/Shmuel Thaler/Santa Cruz Sentinel

item.title: Voices from the protests: 'People of all races out risking their lives to march'
item.dc:creator: Julia Wick, Jaclyn Cosgrove, Maria L. La Ganga, Sonali Kohli, Andrea Castillo
item.description: Protesters in Southern California are a mix of ages and races, fueled by anger at George Floyd's death and at inequality laid bare by a pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Protesters in Southern California are a mix of ages and races, fueled by anger at George Floyd's death and at inequality laid bare by a pandemic.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 02: Protesters and Clergy members from the Los Angeles area participate in a march and peaceful protest in downtown Los Angeles outside of LA City Hall and LAPD Headquarters on Tuesday, June 2, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Protests erupted across the country, with people outraged over the death of George Floyd, a black man killed after a white Minneapolis police officer pinned him to the ground with his knee. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Huge, peaceful protests spread across L.A. and end in more arrests
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia, Dorany Pineda, Alejandra Reyes-Velarde, Sarah Parvini, Hannah Fry, Laura Newberry

item.title: Los Angeles police shoot, wound person in Adams-Normandie neighborhood
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Los Angeles police shot a person, non-fatally, in the Adams-Normandie neighborhood on Monday night, a spokesman for the agency said.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles police shot a person, non-fatally, in the Adams-Normandie neighborhood on Monday night, a spokesman for the agency said.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles CA. JUNE 2, 2020 - An investigation is underway following an officer-involved shooting that occurred shortly before 9:30 p.m. Monday night, June 1, 2020, near the intersection of Vermont Avenue and 22nd Street, just south of the 10 Freeway.

item.title: George Floyd protesters tell San Francisco mayor and police chief they want 'consequences and repercussions'
item.dc:creator: Johana Bhuiyan
item.description: Hundreds of protesters gathered Monday on front of the steps of San Francisco City Hall, demanding "consequences and repercussions" for the police who killed George Floyd.
item.content:encoded: Hundreds of protesters gathered Monday on front of the steps of San Francisco City Hall, demanding "consequences and repercussions" for the police who killed George Floyd.

media:content.media:description: San Francisco Mayor London Breed urges the public to stay at home.

item.description: Thousands of protesters gathered in downtown Riverside on Monday afternoon to call for justice in the death of George Floyd and others killed by police.
item.content:encoded: Thousands of protesters gathered in downtown Riverside on Monday afternoon to call for justice in the death of George Floyd and others killed by police.

media:content.media:description: RIVERSIDE, CA - JUNE 1, 2020: Demonstrators retreat as Riverside County Sheriffs fire non-lethal rounds after law enforcement announced an unlawful assembly and protesters did not leave during the coronavirus pandemic on June 1, 2020 in Riverside, California. Thousands of protesters marched through the street of downtown Riverside and police alloyed them to stay 90 minutes after the 6pm curfew.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: First pregnant woman and first jail inmate die from coronavirus, L.A. County officials say
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Los Angeles County officials reported Monday an additional 22 coronavirus-linked deaths, including a pregnant woman who had tested positive for the virus and had underlying health issues and a person who was incarcerated in a jail facility.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County officials reported Monday an additional 22 coronavirus-linked deaths, including a pregnant woman who had tested positive for the virus and had underlying health issues and a person who was incarcerated in a jail facility.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MARCH 04 , 2020 - L.A. County Department of Public Health Director Barbara Ferrer addresses a press conference held at the steps of Kenneth Hahn Hall of Administration to declare a health emergency as the number of coronavirus cases increased to seven, with six new cases in Los Angeles County. None of the new cases are connected to "community spread," officials said. All individuals were exposed to COVID-19 through close contacts. The additional cases were confirmed Tuesday night. Officials said three of the new cases were travelers who had visited northern Italy, two were family members who had close contact with someone outside of the county who was infected, and one had a job that put them in contact with travelers. One person has been hospitalized, and the others are isolated at home. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times

item.title: An LAPD officer takes a knee, to cheers of Hollywood protesters
item.dc:creator: Julia Wick, Matt Hamilton
item.description: At huge Hollywood protest, an LAPD officer takes to his knee
item.content:encoded: At huge Hollywood protest, an LAPD officer takes to his knee

media:content.media:description: LAPD Commander Operation West Bureau Corey Palka asked the crowd in West Hollywood that if he took the knee, would they agree to make the protest peaceful. He heard screams of support, then got to his knee to more applause.

item.title: Meet the immigrant shop owner who had his business trashed in Santa Monica
item.dc:creator: James Rainey
item.description: Moe, an immigrant from Iran, had his Santa Monica shop trashed by looters Sunday. He questions why the police didn't cut off the looters before they got downtown.
item.content:encoded: Moe, an immigrant from Iran, had his Santa Monica shop trashed by looters Sunday. He questions why the police didn't cut off the looters before they got downtown.

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CA - JUNE 1, 2020 - - Moe T., owner of Santa Monica Tobacco, walks through his business that was looted and burned Sunday in Santa Monica on May 31, 2020. His neighbors, Jason Gochin and Cevin Clark, co-owners of Harvelle's, helped put out the fire started by looters at Moe's store. Their actions prevented the building from being burned down. This photo was taken the day after the looting on June 1, 2020. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Looting reported in Van Nuys as protests over George Floyd's death continue
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Cosgrove
item.description: Dozens of Los Angeles police officers lined Van Nuys Boulevard near Victory Boulevard in Van Nuys late Monday afternoon after reports of looting in the area.
item.content:encoded: Dozens of Los Angeles police officers lined Van Nuys Boulevard near Victory Boulevard in Van Nuys late Monday afternoon after reports of looting in the area.

(Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: Cities are being destroyed. California clearly isn't as enlightened about race as we think

Protests erupted across the country, with people outraged over the death of George Floyd, a black man killed after a white Minneapolis police officer pinned him to the ground with his knee. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: After George Floyd's death, California schools chief vows to address bias
item.dc:creator: Sonali Kohli
item.description: After George Floyd protests, the California Department of Education will focus more on addressing implicit bias in classrooms, Tony Thurmond said.
item.content:encoded: After George Floyd protests, the California Department of Education will focus more on addressing implicit bias in classrooms, Tony Thurmond said.

item.title: South Coast Plaza postpones reopening as protests, looting rock California
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The upscale mall in Costa Mesa had planned to throw open its doors to customers Monday following a lengthy coronavirus-related closure but will remain closed indefinitely.
item.content:encoded: The upscale mall in Costa Mesa had planned to throw open its doors to customers Monday following a lengthy coronavirus-related closure but will remain closed indefinitely.

media:content.media:description: COSTA MESA, CA -- MAY 15: Customers waiting in the return queue, receive instruction from a Nordstrom employee at curbside pickup outside Nordstrom at South Coast Plaza on Friday, May 15, 2020, in Costa Mesa, CA. South Coast Plaza has joined the list of outlets offering contact-free pickup for customers amid the coronavirus pandemic. Customers remain in their auto while their items are put in their car's trunk. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: National Guard arrives in Sacramento, as protests, mayhem rage in much of the Bay Area
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria, Stuart Leavenworth
item.description: Protesters took to the streets again Sunday night in response to the death of George Floyd, but interspersed with peaceful marchers were groups intent on vandalism and stealing.
item.content:encoded: Protesters took to the streets again Sunday night in response to the death of George Floyd, but interspersed with peaceful marchers were groups intent on vandalism and stealing.

media:content.media:description: A man jumps on a vandalized CHP squad car in Oakland on Sunday during another night of demonstrations against the killing of two unarmed black men by police in Ferguson, Mo., and New York.

item.title: First California prison officer dies after contracting coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Danny Mendoza, the first California prison officer to die after contracting coronavirus, worked at the California Rehabilitation Center in Norco.
item.content:encoded: Danny Mendoza, the first California prison officer to die after contracting coronavirus, worked at the California Rehabilitation Center in Norco.

media:content.media:description: Staff from the California Rehabilitation Center, California Highway Patrol, Riverside County Fire Department and coroner's office and the Corona fire and police departments held a vehicle procession Saturday to honor Correctional Officer Danny Mendoza, 53, who died after being diagnosed with the coronavirus.
media:content.media:credit: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation

item.content:encoded: The looting hit large chain businesses like Vans, Vons, banks and other retailers in and around the Santa Monica Place mall. But small business owners also were targeted.

item.description: Authorities said the woman who was shot in Hollywood was stabbing another woman, who ultimately died in the attack.
item.content:encoded: Authorities said the woman who was shot in Hollywood was stabbing another woman, who ultimately died in the attack.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles police officers shot and wounded a woman after they allegedly found her stabbing another person to death.

item.title: Long Beach police swamped by looting; National Guard arrives
item.dc:creator: Ruben Vives
item.description: While hundreds in Long Beach demonstrated against the police killing of George Floyd, a separate group began robbing stores in the Pike Outlets a block away.
item.content:encoded: While hundreds in Long Beach demonstrated against the police killing of George Floyd, a separate group began robbing stores in the Pike Outlets a block away.

media:content.media:description: LONG BEACH CALIF. - MAY 31, 2020. Looters ransack a strip mall at the intersection of Seventh Street and Long Beach Boulevard in Long Beach on Sunday, May 31, 2020. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Climbing out from coronavirus: Northern California county sags under weight of economic crash
item.dc:creator: Joe Mozingo
item.description: Their remoteness hasn't spared them from the economic fallout of the shutdown. And the sparsity of COVID-19 cases in this Northern California county has only made the restrictive measures hobbling their livelihoods all the more exasperating.
item.content:encoded: Their remoteness hasn't spared them from the economic fallout of the shutdown. And the sparsity of COVID-19 cases in this Northern California county has only made the restrictive measures hobbling their livelihoods all the more exasperating.

media:content.media:description: GRASS VALLEY, CA-MAY 22, 2020: Lisa Shippers, center, owner of Old Town Cafe in Grass Valley, talks with Grass Valley residents Sabrina Hocking, 31, left, and her mother, Judith Hocking, 63, as they wait for their breakfast to arrive. The cafe fully re-opened on May 13, previously doing curbside only pick-up due to the coronavirus outbreak. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Thousands of immigrants are stuck in ICE centers. Getting out depends on the judge
item.dc:creator: Andrea Castillo
item.description: In response to lawsuits and public pressure, ICE has released hundreds of immigrants from detention facilities. Others have been released after paying bond.
item.content:encoded: In response to lawsuits and public pressure, ICE has released hundreds of immigrants from detention facilities. Others have been released after paying bond.

media:content.media:description: ADELANTO, CA - NOVEMBER 15: A guard escorts an immigrant detainee from his 'segregation cell' back into the general population at the Adelanto Detention Facility on November 15, 2013 in Adelanto, California. Most detainees in segregation cells are sent there for fighting with other immigrants, according to guards. The facility, the largest and newest Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), detention center in California, houses an average of 1,100 immigrants in custody pending a decision in their immigration cases or awaiting deportation. The average stay for a detainee is 29 days. The facility is managed by the private GEO Group. ICE detains an average of 33,000 undocumented immigrants in more than 400 facilities nationwide. (Photo by John Moore/Getty Images)

item.title: LAPD focused on peaceful protesters while ignoring looting, business owners say
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector, Richard Winton
item.description: Despite efforts by the mayor and police chief to strike the right tone in their response to the protests over the death of George Floyd, many in Los Angeles say they missed the mark.
item.content:encoded: Despite efforts by the mayor and police chief to strike the right tone in their response to the protests over the death of George Floyd, many in Los Angeles say they missed the mark.

media:content.media:description: Santa Monica, CA, Sunday May 31, 2020 - Looters rush away from police after picking through a store downtown plunder stores as protestors face off with police as unrest continues in the wake of the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Officials fear protests are 'super-spreader' events for coronavirus. Marchers say worth the risk
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes, Soumya Karlamangla
item.description: Officials fear protests are 'super-spreader' events for coronavirus. Marchers say worth the risk
item.content:encoded: Officials fear protests are 'super-spreader' events for coronavirus. Marchers say worth the risk

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 31: Protesters raise their arms chanting "Hands up, don't shoot!" during a protest at Pershing Square in downtown Los Angeles on Sunday, May 31, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. About 400 protesters took part to draw attention to the death of George Floyd and Black Lives Matter. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Myung J. Chun/Myung J. Chun/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Column: We are all horrified, but only white people have the luxury of being shocked
item.dc:creator: Mary McNamara
item.description: White people who want to be allies need to worry less about the George Floyd protests and more about the systemic racism that sparked them.
item.content:encoded: White people who want to be allies need to worry less about the George Floyd protests and more about the systemic racism that sparked them.

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CALIFORNIA MAY 31, 2020-Protestors embrace as another is led away in handcuffs on 5th St. in Santa Maonica Sunday. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A., wracked by looting and upheaval, turns yet again to the National Guard
item.dc:creator: David Zahniser, Monte Morin, Thomas Curwen
item.description: The National Guard was deployed in L.A. during periods of unrest in 1965 and 1992, and after the Northridge earthquake in 1994. On Sunday, Humvees rolled through downtown after Mayor Eric Garcetti requested 1,000 troops.
item.content:encoded: The National Guard was deployed in L.A. during periods of unrest in 1965 and 1992, and after the Northridge earthquake in 1994. On Sunday, Humvees rolled through downtown after Mayor Eric Garcetti requested 1,000 troops.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 31: The California National Guard is deployed at City Hall in downtown Los Angeles on Sunday, May 31, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Myung J. Chun/Myung J. Chun/Los Angeles Times

item.title: 'Who approved this?' Riders, officials criticize Metro's systemwide shutdown
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson
item.description: L.A.'s transit system was shut down as protests raged Saturday night over concerns over employees' safety. One L.A. councilman called it "unconscionable."
item.content:encoded: L.A.'s transit system was shut down as protests raged Saturday night over concerns over employees' safety. One L.A. councilman called it "unconscionable."

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA MAY 29, 2020-An MTA bus is vandalized in Downtown Los Angeles Friday. Protestors marched across the nation after the death of George Floyd. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Looting in Van Nuys, Hollywood, as curfew begins in L.A. County
item.dc:creator: Matt Hamilton, Alene Tchekmedyian, Jaclyn Cosgrove, Julia Wick, Matthew Ormseth, Laura J. Nelson
item.description: A third night of curfews followed days of massive, mostly peaceful protests to decry George Floyd's death in Minneapolis.
item.content:encoded: A third night of curfews followed days of massive, mostly peaceful protests to decry George Floyd's death in Minneapolis.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 02: Los Angeles Police Department Commander Gerald Woodyard joins in taking a knee with protesters and clergy members from the Los Angeles area in a march in downtown Los Angeles near LA City Hall and LAPD Headquarters Tuesday, June 02, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Protests have erupted across the country, with people outraged over the death of George Floyd, a black man killed after a white Minneapolis police officer pinned him to the ground with his knee. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Skelton: To solve California's coronavirus-fueled budget woes, Newsom should gamble on sports betting
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: Democratic Sen. Bill Dodd of Napa and Assemblyman Adam Gray of Merced are proposing that California finally legalize sports betting â as 23 other states have done â and reap several hundred million dollars annually in 'sin' taxes.
item.content:encoded: Democratic Sen. Bill Dodd of Napa and Assemblyman Adam Gray of Merced are proposing that California finally legalize sports betting â as 23 other states have done â and reap several hundred million dollars annually in 'sin' taxes.

media:content.media:description: Amado Nanalang watches basketball games while making bets at a sports book in Las Vegas.

item.title: Man shot to death in downtown Los Angeles amid protests Sunday
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth, Richard Winton
item.description: A man was shot to death Sunday evening, according to the Los Angeles Police Department, a killing committed in an area of downtown Los Angeles that was flooded with protesters decrying police brutality.
item.content:encoded: A man was shot to death Sunday evening, according to the Los Angeles Police Department, a killing committed in an area of downtown Los Angeles that was flooded with protesters decrying police brutality.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. - MAY 30, 2020. Police officers stand outside a looted store on Broadway in downtown Los Angeles on Saturday, May 30, 2020. About 200 people marched through downtown streets, slowing traffic and keeping ahead of police trying to cut them off. Looting and the destruction of public and private property has spread across the country in the wake of the the police killing of George Floyd, a black man in Minneapolis. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Thousands of cars protest in caravan through Oakland
item.dc:creator: Johana Bhuiyan
item.description: A procession of thousands of cars snaked through Oakland on Sunday to demand justice for the killing of George Floyd in Minnesota.
item.content:encoded: A procession of thousands of cars snaked through Oakland on Sunday to demand justice for the killing of George Floyd in Minnesota.

media:content.media:description: A car participates in a caravan protest in Oakland on Sunday.

item.title: L.A. County courts are ordered closed Monday due to protests
item.dc:creator: Laura Newberry
item.description: All Los Angeles County court proceedings will be suspended through at least Monday in response to ongoing protests.
item.content:encoded: All Los Angeles County court proceedings will be suspended through at least Monday in response to ongoing protests.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 18, 2017 -- The Stanley Mosk Courthouse, which is the main civil courthouse of the Superior Court of Los Angeles County in downtown Los Angeles on May 18, 2017. California's court leaders expressed alarm Wednesday over a new study that showed more than 100 courthouses in the state - including many in Los Angeles County - could collapse and cause "substantial" loss of life in a major earthquake. Courthouses near the top of the list of buildings in peril include the Stanley Mosk Courthouse and Clara Shortridge Foltz Criminal Justice Center, the Pasadena municipal courthouse, and courthouses in Beverly Hills and Burbank. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 13 arrested in attempt to loot Lakewood mall, sheriff says
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: Sheriff's deputies were out in force at the shopping center, and Sheriff Alex Villanueva said they were able to quickly control the situation.
item.content:encoded: Sheriff's deputies were out in force at the shopping center, and Sheriff Alex Villanueva said they were able to quickly control the situation.

item.title: Melrose Avenue, one of L.A.'s hippest streets, hit hard by looters
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia, Joseph Serna, Laura Newberry
item.description: Business owners on Melrose Avenue in the Fairfax District were forced to take stock Sunday after a night of civil unrest gave way to mayhem.
item.content:encoded: Business owners on Melrose Avenue in the Fairfax District were forced to take stock Sunday after a night of civil unrest gave way to mayhem.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES-CA-MAY 31, 2020: A storefront on Melrose Avenue is shattered on Sunday, May 31, 2020. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: LAPD officer is shot in the leg at Whole Foods parking lot in Venice
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: The incident occurred about 4:30 p.m. in the area of the Whole Foods parking lot near Lincoln Boulevard and Rose Avenue.
item.content:encoded: The incident occurred about 4:30 p.m. in the area of the Whole Foods parking lot near Lincoln Boulevard and Rose Avenue.

media:content.media:description: An LAPD patrol car rushes through the intersection of La Brea Avenue and Venice Boulevard in April.
